articles.headline: In Shirt-Sleeve Holiday Season, Overcoats Linger on the Racks
articles.snippet: Balmy temperatures on East Coast, with average highs this holiday season 15 degrees warmer than last year, have been disastrous for sales of all kinds of cold-weather clothing; glut of winter wear has sent chill through executive suites of major r...
articles.abstract: Balmy temperatures on East Coast, with average highs this holiday season 15 degrees warmer than last year, have been disastrous for sales of all kinds of cold-weather clothing; glut of winter wear has sent chill through executive suites of major retailers, who count on big profits from coats in crucial holiday shopping season; they are even starting to grumble about first 'global warming Christmas'; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Retailers are calling it the Coat Crisis of 2006, a fashion fiasco measured in racks of unsold fur-lined shearlings at Saks Fifth Avenue and down puffer jackets at Bloomingdale's.

articles.headline: Toyota Is Poised to Supplant G.M. as World’s Largest Carmaker
articles.snippet: Toyota Motor Corp issues forecast saying it will supplant General Motors, which has been at top in sales since 1931, in 2007; says it expects to sell 9.34 milion vehicles next year, which would exceed 9.2 million vehicles that GM expects to sell w...
articles.abstract: Toyota Motor Corp issues forecast saying it will supplant General Motors, which has been at top in sales since 1931, in 2007; says it expects to sell 9.34 milion vehicles next year, which would exceed 9.2 million vehicles that GM expects to sell worldwide; Toyota's ascension is remarkable because it has reached top by borrowing many ideas from American makers and improving upon them; photo; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Dec. 22 - After 75 years, the world automobile industry is about to get a new No. 1.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: You’ve Hit the Jackpot. Now What?
articles.snippet: Interview with Yul Kwon, Silicon Valley business strategic consultant and winner of television show Survivor: Cook Islands; he and financial planners offer advice on what to do with winnings; photo (M)
articles.abstract: Interview with Yul Kwon, Silicon Valley business strategic consultant and winner of television show Survivor: Cook Islands; he and financial planners offer advice on what to do with winnings; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Yul Kwon just won $1 million on the television show "Survivor: Cook Islands." What's he going to do with that windfall?

articles.headline: You’ve Hit the Jackpot. Now What?
articles.snippet: If you fall into a lot of cash, you should pause before you spend and think about how much you’ve really won and how you relate to money.
articles.abstract: If you fall into a lot of cash, you should pause before you spend and think about how much you’ve really won and how you relate to money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yul Kwon just won $1 million on the television show “Survivor: Cook Islands.” What’s he going to do with that windfall?

articles.headline: Canned Phrases for Making an Exit
articles.snippet: Corporate executives, even those in the thick of scandal, routinely cite a desire to spend more time with family when they resign from office.
articles.abstract: Corporate executives, even those in the thick of scandal, routinely cite a desire to spend more time with family when they resign from office.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a turn of phrase with a long tradition, spun from corporate boardrooms in all seeming sincerity — no winks, no nods — just the sober announcement.

articles.headline: District by District, Shiites Make Baghdad Their Own
articles.snippet: Large portions of Baghdad have become Shiite in recent months, as militias press their fight against Sunni militants deeper into heart of capital, displacing thousands of Sunni residents; at least 10 neighborhoods that year ago were mixed Sunni an...
articles.abstract: Large portions of Baghdad have become Shiite in recent months, as militias press their fight against Sunni militants deeper into heart of capital, displacing thousands of Sunni residents; at least 10 neighborhoods that year ago were mixed Sunni and Shiite are almost entirely Shiite; Sunni militants were dominant during first years of war, forcing Shiites out of neighborhoods and killing bakers, barbers and trash collectors, who were often Shiites; Shiite militias began to strike back after bombing of shrine in Samarra in Feb; Shiite-dominated government publicly condemns violence against Sunnis, but attacks have continued unabated; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 22 - As the United States debates what to do in Iraq, this country's Shiite majority has been moving toward its own solution: making the capital its own.

articles.headline: District by District, Shiites Make Baghdad Their Own
articles.snippet: Shiite militias are pushing thousands of Sunni residents from once-mixed neighborhoods.
articles.abstract: Shiite militias are pushing thousands of Sunni residents from once-mixed neighborhoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 22 — As the United States debates what to do in Iraq, this country’s Shiite majority has been moving toward its own solution: making the capital its own.

articles.headline: Seductively Easy, Payday Loans Often Snowball
articles.snippet: Short-term “payday loans,” which charge high interest rates for quick cash, are effectively banned in 11 states but are flourishing in the other 39.
articles.abstract: Short-term “payday loans,” which charge high interest rates for quick cash, are effectively banned in 11 states but are flourishing in the other 39.
articles.lead_paragraph: GALLUP, N.M., Dec. 20 — Earl Milford put up an artificial Christmas tree in the wooden house on the Navajo reservation near here that he shares with a son and daughter-in-law and their two little girls.

articles.headline: Editors' Note
articles.snippet: Joe Nocera, whose column normally appears on this page, is on temporary leave.
articles.abstract: Joe Nocera, whose column normally appears on this page, is on temporary leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Nocera, whose column normally appears on this page, is on temporary leave.

articles.headline: A Joint Attack on Many Perils of Africa’s Young
articles.snippet: Campaigns were carried out in nine African countries this year to better children’s odds of surviving past their fifth birthdays.
articles.abstract: Campaigns were carried out in nine African countries this year to better children’s odds of surviving past their fifth birthdays.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONYAMAYIRI, Ghana — In this poor, dusty village of 550 people, four babies died of malaria in October, among them 11-month-old Yire Are. As word spread that the government would be handing out mosquito nets that prevent malaria, his uncle made sure he was there with his own children, their heads shaved in mourning.

articles.headline: From Scum, Perhaps the Tiniest Form of Life
articles.snippet: The smallest form of life known to science just got smaller.      Four million of a newly discovered microbe -- assuming the discovery, reported yesterday in the journal Science, is confirmed -- could fit into the period at the end of this sentenc...
articles.abstract: The smallest form of life known to science just got smaller.      Four million of a newly discovered microbe -- assuming the discovery, reported yesterday in the journal Science, is confirmed -- could fit into the period at the end of this sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The smallest form of life known to science just got smaller.

articles.headline: In Shirt-Sleeve Holiday Season, Overcoats Linger on the Racks
articles.snippet: Balmy temperatures on the East Coast have been disastrous for sales of cold-weather clothing.
articles.abstract: Balmy temperatures on the East Coast have been disastrous for sales of cold-weather clothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retailers are calling it the Coat Crisis of 2006, a fashion fiasco measured in racks of unsold fur-lined shearlings at Saks Fifth Avenue and down puffer jackets at Bloomingdale’s.

articles.headline: Canned Phrases for Making an Exit
articles.snippet: Article on use by top executives of stock expressions, sometimes in midst of investigation into criminal activity, to explain why they are leaving their companies; two most frequently used lines are 'spending more time with your family' and 'leavi...
articles.abstract: Article on use by top executives of stock expressions, sometimes in midst of investigation into criminal activity, to explain why they are leaving their companies; two most frequently used lines are 'spending more time with your family' and 'leaving to pursue other interests'; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a turn of phrase with a long tradition, spun from corporate boardrooms in all seeming sincerity -- no winks, no nods -- just the sober announcement.

articles.headline: Toyota Is Poised to Supplant G.M. as World’s Largest Carmaker
articles.snippet: Toyota’s plans to sell 9.34 million vehicles in 2007 would make it the world’s largest auto company, analysts said.
articles.abstract: Toyota’s plans to sell 9.34 million vehicles in 2007 would make it the world’s largest auto company, analysts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Dec. 22 — After 75 years, the world automobile industry is about to get a new No. 1.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Deal Done by Murdoch and Malone
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch’s Christmas present to himself is a John Malone-free new year and a firmer grip on his media conglomerate.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s Christmas present to himself is a John Malone-free new year and a firmer grip on his media conglomerate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s Christmas present to himself is a John Malone-free new year and a firmer grip on his media conglomerate.

articles.headline: Deal Done by Murdoch and Malone
articles.snippet: News Corp chief executive Rupert Murdoch seals deal with John Malone's Liberty Media, trading News Corp's 38 percent stake in DirecTV and some other assets for Liberty's 19 percent of News Corp; deal, valued at roughly $11 billion, removes threat ...
articles.abstract: News Corp chief executive Rupert Murdoch seals deal with John Malone's Liberty Media, trading News Corp's 38 percent stake in DirecTV and some other assets for Liberty's 19 percent of News Corp; deal, valued at roughly $11 billion, removes threat of Liberty using its stake in News Corp to someday challenge hold of Murdoch family; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch's Christmas present to himself is a John Malone-free new year and a firmer grip on his media conglomerate.

articles.headline: Charges of Rape Against 3 at Duke Are Dropped
articles.snippet: Dist Atty Michael B Nifong drops rape charges against former Duke lacrosse players David F Evans, Collin Finnerty and Reade Seligmann, but says he will continue to pursue kidnapping and sexual offense charges that carry equally stiff sentences; Ni...
articles.abstract: Dist Atty Michael B Nifong drops rape charges against former Duke lacrosse players David F Evans, Collin Finnerty and Reade Seligmann, but says he will continue to pursue kidnapping and sexual offense charges that carry equally stiff sentences; Nifong, who has faced rising criticism for his handling of case, says he dismissed rape charges because accuser had begun to waiver on crucial details; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 22 - The Durham district attorney dropped rape charges against three former Duke lacrosse players on Friday, but he said he would continue to pursue kidnapping and sexual offense charges that carry equally stiff sentences.
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Seductively Easy, Payday Loans Often Snowball
articles.snippet: Earl Milford, who lives on Navajo reservation near Gallup, NM, is chronically broke because each month he pays $1,500 a month just to cover interest on what he had intended several years ago to be short-term 'payday loans'; other residents of Gall...
articles.abstract: Earl Milford, who lives on Navajo reservation near Gallup, NM, is chronically broke because each month he pays $1,500 a month just to cover interest on what he had intended several years ago to be short-term 'payday loans'; other residents of Gallup area and countless people across country are visiting payday lenders in December to get advances of few hundred dollars to help with holiday expenses; such lending is banned in 11 states, including New York, through usury or other laws, but it is flourishing in other 39; practice is unusually rampant and unregulated in New Mexico, where Center for Responsible Lending, private consumer group, calculates that nationally payday loans totaled at least $28 billion in 2005; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: A Joint Attack on Many Perils of Africa's Young
articles.snippet: Final article in series, On the Brink, notes that battle against malaria in Africa has benefited from combined campaigns to treat and prevent common and deadly diseases, but organizational and coordination issues have complicated effort; Ghana has...
articles.abstract: Final article in series, On the Brink, notes that battle against malaria in Africa has benefited from combined campaigns to treat and prevent common and deadly diseases, but organizational and coordination issues have complicated effort; Ghana has started integrated effort to reduce infant mortality that includes vaccinations for polio and measles, and nets to prevent malaria; similar drives have unfolded in eight other countries across Africa, with mosquito nets alone expected to save lives of 370,000 children over next three years; Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria has rejected $46 million proposal to expand approach to six more African countries; main problem is that each drive against a disease has its own leaders, charitable groups and donors, and piecing them together in unified campaigns requires logistical skills and diplomatic finesse of battlefield commander; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: PONYAMAYIRI, Ghana - In this poor, dusty village of 550 people, four babies died of malaria in October, among them 11-month-old Yire Are. As word spread that the government would be handing out mosquito nets that prevent malaria, his uncle made sure he was there with his own children, their heads shaved in mourning.

articles.headline: A Lump of Coal Might Suffice
articles.snippet: Reminded again that performance and pay are not always linked.
articles.abstract: Reminded again that performance and pay are not always linked.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE’S hoping that Hank McKinnell, the former chief executive of Pfizer, chose a giant Sequoia for his Christmas tree this year, because there is no way he could fit the $200 million gift that his old board gave him a few days ago under a mere Fraser fir.

articles.headline: Back in Style: The Fur Trade
articles.snippet: Fur has gone casual, and is even paired with jeans to suit the young shopper.
articles.abstract: Fur has gone casual, and is even paired with jeans to suit the young shopper.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOM DeLISLE, sporting thigh-high waders, squishes through mud and cattails surrounding a pond near Albany, looking for wayward beavers that might have wandered into one of his underwater traps. Alas, his instant-kill traps, baited with Backbreaker castor oil, are empty. But Mr. DeLisle plans to keep trapping all winter, knowing that the pelts of beavers and other animals will grow thicker — and may fetch a better price when he sells them — as the months wear on.

articles.headline: Gender Pay Gap, Once Narrowing, Is Stuck in Place
articles.snippet: Article in series The New Gender Divide finds that pay gap between women and men with four-year college degrees ages 36 to 45 has widened slightly since mid-1990s, after narrowing in 1980's; women's pay fell to 74.7 cents in hourly pay for every d...
articles.abstract: Article in series The New Gender Divide finds that pay gap between women and men with four-year college degrees ages 36 to 45 has widened slightly since mid-1990s, after narrowing in 1980's; women's pay fell to 74.7 cents in hourly pay for every dollar men earned in 2005 from 75.7 cents a decade earlier; reasons are complex and appear to include both discrimination and women's choices; some economists say women would have greater opportunity to pursue whatever job they wanted if government provided daycare programs, but another view is that women consider money top priority less often than do men; graph; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the 1980s and early '90s, women of all economic levels -- poor, middle class and rich -- were steadily gaining ground on their male counterparts in the work force. By the mid-'90s, women earned more than 75 cents for every dollar in hourly pay that men did, up from 65 cents just 15 years earlier.

articles.headline: DNA Witness Jolted Dynamic of Duke Case
articles.snippet: Admission by Brian W Meehan that his preliminary report on DNA material in Duke lacrosse rape case was intentionally incomplete through agreement with Durham County District Atty Michael B Nifong adds substantiality to long list of questions about...
articles.abstract: Admission by Brian W Meehan that his preliminary report on DNA material in Duke lacrosse rape case was intentionally incomplete through agreement with Durham County District Atty Michael B Nifong adds substantiality to long list of questions about accuser's credibility and Nifong's judgment; Nifong has dropped rape charges but has said he will proceed with kidnapping and sexual offense counts; claims defense attack on DNA report reveals ruthless strategy aimed at vilifying him and intimidating victim of brutal assault; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 23 - The moment that may have changed the course of the Duke lacrosse rape case came in a packed courtroom two Fridays ago.
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Hotel Log Hints at Illicit Desire That Dr. Freud Didn’t Repress
articles.snippet: Signatures left in a Swiss hotel register appear to prove an affair between Sigmund Freud and his wife’s younger sister.
articles.abstract: Signatures left in a Swiss hotel register appear to prove an affair between Sigmund Freud and his wife’s younger sister.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was just a Freudian slip. Or a case of hiding in plain sight.

articles.headline: One Degree in Fine Arts, and One in Plumbing
articles.snippet: Elaine Ward is one of a small number of women who work as plumbers in New York City.
articles.abstract: Elaine Ward is one of a small number of women who work as plumbers in New York City.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Elaine Ward became an apprentice plumber in 1986, the only female plumber most Americans had ever seen was Josephine the Plumber, a character in 1960s and ’70s commercials for Comet cleanser.

articles.headline: A Lump of Coal Might Suffice
articles.snippet: Gretchen Morgenson column on $200 million severance package Pfizer has given to former chief executive Hank McKinnell; says package is indicative of how much executive compensation can remain hidden from shareholders; photo (M)
articles.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on $200 million severance package Pfizer has given to former chief executive Hank McKinnell; says package is indicative of how much executive compensation can remain hidden from shareholders; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE'S hoping that Hank McKinnell, the former chief executive of Pfizer, chose a giant Sequoia for his Christmas tree this year, because there is no way he could fit the $200 million gift that his old board gave him a few days ago under a mere Fraser fir.

articles.headline: Commander Said to Be Open to More Troops
articles.snippet: Altering his earlier position, the top American ground commander in Iraq is now willing to back an increase in U.S. troops in Baghdad.
articles.abstract: Altering his earlier position, the top American ground commander in Iraq is now willing to back an increase in U.S. troops in Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 — The American military command in Iraq is now willing to back a temporary increase in American troops in Baghdad as part of a broader Iraqi and United States effort to stem the slide toward chaos, senior American officials said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: DNA Witness Jolted Dynamic of Duke Case
articles.snippet: A laboratory director’s testimony added to a list of questions on the accuser’s credibility and the district attorney’s judgment.
articles.abstract: A laboratory director’s testimony added to a list of questions on the accuser’s credibility and the district attorney’s judgment.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 23 — The moment that may have changed the course of the Duke lacrosse rape case came in a packed courtroom two Fridays ago.
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Testing the Water, Obama Tests His Own Limits
articles.snippet: Sen Barack Obama faces complex matrix of questions around his prospective candidacy in 2008 presidential election; first-term liberal Democrat could simply be long on charisma and enjoying brief moment of fame, or could be real post-partisan, post...
articles.abstract: Sen Barack Obama faces complex matrix of questions around his prospective candidacy in 2008 presidential election; first-term liberal Democrat could simply be long on charisma and enjoying brief moment of fame, or could be real post-partisan, post-racial and post-baby boom embodiment of new brand of politics; campaign could highlight Obama's strength as lyrical communicator or expose shortcomings of young politician not yet fully developed; Obama is likely to draw intense and unflattering scrutiny, particularly if he goes head to head with Sen Hillary Clinton; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 - On a winter afternoon two years ago, Senator Barack Obama took his oath of office and strolled across the Capitol grounds hand-in-hand with his wife and two daughters. At the time, a question from his 6-year-old sounded precocious. Now, it seems prescient.

articles.headline: Commander Said to Be Open to More Troops
articles.snippet: New Defense Sec Robert Gates tells Pres Bush that top commander in Iraq Gen George W Casey has reversed his position and is now open to more American troops in Iraq; Casey had feared move would increase Iraqi dependency on United States; winning s...
articles.abstract: New Defense Sec Robert Gates tells Pres Bush that top commander in Iraq Gen George W Casey has reversed his position and is now open to more American troops in Iraq; Casey had feared move would increase Iraqi dependency on United States; winning support of commanders is politically crucial for Bush if he hopes to make troop increase part of his strategy; analysts say key to any new strategy would be binding commitment by Iraqi government to take more steps to slow sectarian violence (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - The American military command in Iraq is now willing to back a temporary increase in American troops in Baghdad as part of a broader Iraqi and United States effort to stem the slide toward chaos, senior American officials said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: For Young Offenders, Justice as Impoverished as Africa
articles.snippet: Africa’s juvenile-justice systems routinely deliver injustice and brutality.
articles.abstract: Africa’s juvenile-justice systems routinely deliver injustice and brutality.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — Set in a wasteland of derelict buildings and furrowed alleys, the Kingtom Remand Home for young lawbreakers here was itself a dilapidated mess, until British donors renovated it in November. Now it boasts a new roof, freshly plastered walls, refurbished dorms and a coat of Kelly-green paint — all in all, a refuge far better than Freetown’s mean streets.

articles.headline: Can Private Equity Build a Public Face?
articles.snippet: A takeover firm that prizes secrecy is also bruised by it.
articles.abstract: A takeover firm that prizes secrecy is also bruised by it.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON the upper floors of a soaring Midtown Manhattan skyscraper, behind heavy glass doors that do not bear his name, sits Stephen A. Feinberg, one of the country’s most powerful — and anonymous — financiers.

articles.headline: Back in Style: The Fur Trade
articles.snippet: Article on robustness of fur market, buoyed by globalization of trade and broader reach of fashion industry; sales of fur garments, trim and accessories reportedly amounted to about $13 billion in fiscal year ended August 2005, increase of 9 perce...
articles.abstract: Article on robustness of fur market, buoyed by globalization of trade and broader reach of fashion industry; sales of fur garments, trim and accessories reportedly amounted to about $13 billion in fiscal year ended August 2005, increase of 9 percent from previous year and 40 percent from five years earlier; beaver and muskrat furs are popular and price of mink has reached all-time high; while some designers have abandoned fur after pressure from animal rights activists, many more have taken it up; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: TOM DeLISLE, sporting thigh-high waders, squishes through mud and cattails surrounding a pond near Albany, looking for wayward beavers that might have wandered into one of his underwater traps. Alas, his instant-kill traps, baited with Backbreaker castor oil, are empty. But Mr. DeLisle plans to keep trapping all winter, knowing that the pelts of beavers and other animals will grow thicker -- and may fetch a better price when he sells them -- as the months wear on.

articles.headline: Can Private Equity Build a Public Face?
articles.snippet: Article on Cerberus Capital Management and its founder Stephen Feinberg; investment fund, which thrives on secrecy, has quietly acquired some of world's best-known companies over last few years; has controlling interest in more than 45 companies t...
articles.abstract: Article on Cerberus Capital Management and its founder Stephen Feinberg; investment fund, which thrives on secrecy, has quietly acquired some of world's best-known companies over last few years; has controlling interest in more than 45 companies that employ more than 250,000 people and generate $50 billion in revenue each year; Cerberus, which has lost out on deals because of its secretive image, is trying to change its image; graph; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: ON the upper floors of a soaring Midtown Manhattan skyscraper, behind heavy glass doors that do not bear his name, sits Stephen A. Feinberg, one of the country's most powerful -- and anonymous -- financiers.

articles.headline: Gender Pay Gap, Once Narrowing, Is Stuck in Place
articles.snippet: A decade ago, it seemed that men and women with similar qualifications might soon make nearly identical salaries. Today, that is far harder to envision.
articles.abstract: A decade ago, it seemed that men and women with similar qualifications might soon make nearly identical salaries. Today, that is far harder to envision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the 1980s and early ’90s, women of all economic levels — poor, middle class and rich — were steadily gaining ground on their male counterparts in the work force. By the mid-’90s, women earned more than 75 cents for every dollar in hourly pay that men did, up from 65 cents just 15 years earlier.

articles.headline: One Degree in Fine Arts, and One in Plumbing
articles.snippet: Elaine Ward, owner of Isis Plumbing in New York City, is one of small number of female plumbers in city, one of few women who own plumbing business in city and one of few women licensed in city as master plumber; Plumbers Local Union 1 says 1 perc...
articles.abstract: Elaine Ward, owner of Isis Plumbing in New York City, is one of small number of female plumbers in city, one of few women who own plumbing business in city and one of few women licensed in city as master plumber; Plumbers Local Union 1 says 1 percent of its 4,600 working members are female; Local 1 participates in new city program to increase women and minorities in unionized construction jobs; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Elaine Ward became an apprentice plumber in 1986, the only female plumber most Americans had ever seen was Josephine the Plumber, a character in 1960s and '70s commercials for Comet cleanser.

articles.headline: For Young Offenders, Justice as Impoverished as Africa
articles.snippet: Juvenile-justice systems in sub-Saharan Africa routinely deliver injustice and brutality despite endorsing international norms and employing dedicated staff; children are locked up with adults or languish in ill-equipped rehabilitation centers; ju...
articles.abstract: Juvenile-justice systems in sub-Saharan Africa routinely deliver injustice and brutality despite endorsing international norms and employing dedicated staff; children are locked up with adults or languish in ill-equipped rehabilitation centers; justice system must compete for money and attention; fundamental problems include widespread lack of birth certificates, which leads officials to regard all but obvious children as adults; cultural attitudes and public sentiments also weigh heavily on juvenile justice efforts; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - Set in a wasteland of derelict buildings and furrowed alleys, the Kingtom Remand Home for young lawbreakers here was itself a dilapidated mess, until British donors renovated it in November. Now it boasts a new roof, freshly plastered walls, refurbished dorms and a coat of Kelly-green paint -- all in all, a refuge far better than Freetown's mean streets.

articles.headline: The Lads Are Getting Picky
articles.snippet: Could it be that the lad magazine genre, which includes publications like Maxim, is keeling over on its way to middle age?
articles.abstract: Could it be that the lad magazine genre, which includes publications like Maxim, is keeling over on its way to middle age?
articles.lead_paragraph: One million used to be something of a magic number in magazine publishing. If you captured a million readers, advertisers took you seriously.

articles.headline: Wall St. Bonuses: So Much Money, Too Few Ferraris
articles.snippet: Investment houses like Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley are awarding bonuses as high as $60 million to their top bankers and traders after year of record profits; select group of hedge fund managers and private equity executives m...
articles.abstract: Investment houses like Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley are awarding bonuses as high as $60 million to their top bankers and traders after year of record profits; select group of hedge fund managers and private equity executives may be taking home even more; 2006 bonus gold rush has re-energized some luxury markets, like Manhattan real estate market; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: It's a brisk Wednesday morning in the windy caverns of Wall Street and Sarah Clark's toes are cold.

articles.headline: The Lads Are Getting Picky
articles.snippet: David Carr column on decline in popularity of so-called lad magazines, or magazines for men; holds British publisher Emap earlier in month pulled plug on FHM, which had circulation of 1.25 million, and left country; notes its advertising dropped 1...
articles.abstract: David Carr column on decline in popularity of so-called lad magazines, or magazines for men; holds British publisher Emap earlier in month pulled plug on FHM, which had circulation of 1.25 million, and left country; notes its advertising dropped 19.7 percent in first 11 months of year; says Maxim, circulation leader in men's category with rate base of 2.5 million, is down 5 percent in advertising pages this year from year before, and lucrative newsstand sales are down more than 200,000 in last three years; says many Web sites are offering same content that these magazines offer (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: One million used to be something of a magic number in magazine publishing. If you captured a million readers, advertisers took you seriously.

articles.headline: Lots of Cheer From R.I.M., but No News on Options
articles.snippet: Research In Motion has offered investors few details about the review of its stock options grants, making it difficult to assess its potential impact.
articles.abstract: Research In Motion has offered investors few details about the review of its stock options grants, making it difficult to assess its potential impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Dec. 24  James L. Balsillie, the chairman and co-chief executive of Research In Motion, offered plenty of cheery news during an investor conference call last week: quarterly profit up 47 percent from the same period a year ago and a sales increase of 49 percent, largely based on the company’s successful move into the consumer market.

articles.headline: At Axis of Episcopal Split, an Anti-Gay Nigerian
articles.snippet: Archbishop Peter J Akinola, conservative leader of Nigeria's Anglican Church, has emerged at center of schism over homosexuality in global Anglican Communion; Akinola, whose international reputation has been built on his tough stance against homos...
articles.abstract: Archbishop Peter J Akinola, conservative leader of Nigeria's Anglican Church, has emerged at center of schism over homosexuality in global Anglican Communion; Akinola, whose international reputation has been built on his tough stance against homosexuality, has become spiritual head of 21 conservative churches in US; they opted to leave Episcopal Church over its decision to consecrate gay bishop and allow churches to bless same-sex unions; Akinola has created offshoot of his Nigerian church in North America for discontented Americans; he has made himself kingpin of alliance between theological conservatives in North America and developing world that could tip power to conservatives in Anglican Communion; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria, Dec. 20 - The way he tells the story, the first and only time Archbishop Peter J. Akinola knowingly shook a gay person's hand, he sprang backward the moment he realized what he had done.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard, Recasting Itself, Is Looking Beyond PCs and Printers
articles.snippet: Consumer electronics is the next challenge for Hewlett-Packard as it sets a goal of growing 6 percent next year and the year after.
articles.abstract: Consumer electronics is the next challenge for Hewlett-Packard as it sets a goal of growing 6 percent next year and the year after.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard is looking for a second act. Several of them, actually.

articles.headline: Wall St. Bonuses: So Much Money, Too Few Ferraris
articles.snippet: After a year of record profits at investment houses, a bonus gold rush has re-energized some luxury markets.
articles.abstract: After a year of record profits at investment houses, a bonus gold rush has re-energized some luxury markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a brisk Wednesday morning in the windy caverns of Wall Street and Sarah Clark’s toes are cold.

articles.headline: Sizzling a Year Ago, but Now Pfffft ...
articles.snippet: Telenovela, low-budget soap opera genre that has become staple television programming in Spanish-speaking countries, fails to gain traction in US; in 12 months since news reports revealed that CBS was working on as many as seven scripts for teleno...
articles.abstract: Telenovela, low-budget soap opera genre that has become staple television programming in Spanish-speaking countries, fails to gain traction in US; in 12 months since news reports revealed that CBS was working on as many as seven scripts for telenovelas, that ABC had invested as many as 45 existing telenovela storylines, and NBC was jumping in to adapt telenovelas already produced by Telemundo, Spanish-language network that NBC owns, not much more has been said--or done; not single telenovela project has been put into production by any of those networks; networks' intense interest in telenovela genre was sparked by need to find alternative, inexpensive programming in summer to replace round of repeats; networks discovered they would only alienate their viewers if they tried to make shows of distinctly lesser quality than their regular shows; also discovered that production schedules required to grind out so many episodes in such short time would be daunting; mini-network called MyNetworkTV, collection of television stations, mainly owned by News Corp, is featuring telenovelas nightly; executives at ABC, CBS and NBC say they still have some telenovela projects in development; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: The telenovela, the steamy low-budget soap opera genre that has become the staple of television programming in Spanish-speaking countries, lives on its sudden bursts of uncontrollable -- and loudly acted -- passion.

articles.headline: Ethiopia Hits Somali Targets, Declaring War
articles.snippet: The escalation could turn Somalia’s internal crisis into a religious conflict that engulfs the Horn of Africa.
articles.abstract: The escalation could turn Somalia’s internal crisis into a religious conflict that engulfs the Horn of Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Dec. 24 — Ethiopia officially plunged into war with Somalia’s Islamist forces on Sunday, bombing targets inside Somalia and pushing ground troops deep into Somali territory in a major escalation that could turn Somalia’s internal crisis into a violent religious conflict that engulfs the entire Horn of Africa.

articles.headline: At Axis of Episcopal Split, an Anti-Gay Nigerian
articles.snippet: Archbishop Peter J. Akinola of Nigeria has become the spiritual head of 21 conservative churches in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Archbishop Peter J. Akinola of Nigeria has become the spiritual head of 21 conservative churches in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria, Dec. 20  The way he tells the story, the first and only time Archbishop Peter J. Akinola knowingly shook a gay person’s hand, he sprang backward the moment he realized what he had done.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Pork No Longer Paves the Road to Re-election
articles.snippet: Timeworn bit of political wisdom has been that larding one's district with pork projects can act as incumbency protection program; Republican leaders in Congress ardently followed that principle; powers of incumbency could not outweigh far more pr...
articles.abstract: Timeworn bit of political wisdom has been that larding one's district with pork projects can act as incumbency protection program; Republican leaders in Congress ardently followed that principle; powers of incumbency could not outweigh far more pressing issues in 2006; abuse of earmarks itself became issue in several races with some of their biggest users losing their seats; it would be premature to write off power of earmarks; Democrats have vowed to strip earmarks from unfinished spending bills, but practice is such oft-used political tool that it may prove too tempting to eliminate; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: PLEASANTON, Calif. - Until this year, Richard W. Pombo, the seven-term Republican congressman from the Central Valley, had never caused much fanfare about bringing home earmarks, the special local projects that circumvent the normal budgeting process. He was far better known for his work fighting environmental regulations.

articles.headline: The Man on the Table Devised the Surgery
articles.snippet: Dr Michael E DeBakey, one of most influential heart surgeons, was 97 when he suffered dissecting aortic aneurysm on Dec 31, 2005; he became oldest survivor of operation he had devised to repair torn aortas, condition virtually always fatal; his tr...
articles.abstract: Dr Michael E DeBakey, one of most influential heart surgeons, was 97 when he suffered dissecting aortic aneurysm on Dec 31, 2005; he became oldest survivor of operation he had devised to repair torn aortas, condition virtually always fatal; his treatment stirred debate over how far to go in treating someone so old, and making risky decisions that can save lives; DeBakey, over past 60 years, has changed way heart surgery is performed, and now he is making history as patient; DeBakey was released from Methodist Hospital in Houston in September and is back at work; at 98, he is oldest survivor of his operation, proving that healthy man of his age can endure it; diagram; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: In late afternoon last Dec. 31, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, then 97, was alone at home in Houston in his study preparing a lecture when a sharp pain ripped through his upper chest and between his shoulder blades, then moved into his neck.

articles.headline: Ethiopia Hits Somali Targets, Declaring War
articles.snippet: Ethiopia officially plunges into war with Somalia's Islamist forces, bombing targets inside Somalia and putting Ethiopian troops on march in escalation that could turn Somalia's internal crisis into religious conflict that engulfs entire Horn of A...
articles.abstract: Ethiopia officially plunges into war with Somalia's Islamist forces, bombing targets inside Somalia and putting Ethiopian troops on march in escalation that could turn Somalia's internal crisis into religious conflict that engulfs entire Horn of Africa; assault is first open admission by Ethiopia's Christian-led government of its military operations inside Somalia, where--with tacit US support--it has been helping weak interim government threatened by forces loyal to Islamic clerics who control capitol Mogadishu and much of country; map; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Dec. 24 - Ethiopia officially plunged into war with Somalia's Islamist forces on Sunday, bombing targets inside Somalia and pushing ground troops deep into Somali territory in a major escalation that could turn Somalia's internal crisis into a violent religious conflict that engulfs the entire Horn of Africa.

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard, Recasting Itself, Is Looking Beyond PCs and Printers
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard is looking beyond personal computers and printers with its next challenge being consumer electronics; $92 billion company has set goal of growing 6 percent next year and year after, meaning it must add about $5.5 billion each year ...
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard is looking beyond personal computers and printers with its next challenge being consumer electronics; $92 billion company has set goal of growing 6 percent next year and year after, meaning it must add about $5.5 billion each year in new revenue; company is moving quickly to build printers for almost any application in which ink hits paper; analysts say it is slam dunk; two other areas that company has identified for growth, selling cost-efficient corporate data centers and consumer electronics, pose considerably more risk; some other consumer electronic products being considered discussed; chief executive Mark V Hurd comments; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard is looking for a second act. Several of them, actually.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Holding Iranians Seized in Raids in Iraq
articles.snippet: At least four Iranians were caught in raids aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces, officials said.
articles.abstract: At least four Iranians were caught in raids aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 24 — The American military is holding at least four Iranians in Iraq, including men the Bush administration called senior military officials, who were seized in a pair of raids late last week aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces, according to senior Iraqi and American officials in Baghdad and Washington.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Flaws Are Detected in Microsoft’s Vista
articles.snippet: Microsoft is facing early crisis of confidence in quality of its Windows Vista operating system as computer security researchers and hackers have begun to find potentially serious flaws in system that was released to corporate customers in late No...
articles.abstract: Microsoft is facing early crisis of confidence in quality of its Windows Vista operating system as computer security researchers and hackers have begun to find potentially serious flaws in system that was released to corporate customers in late November; browser flaw is particularly troubling because it potentially means that Web users could become infected with malicious software by visiting booby-trapped site; Determina, which sells software intended to protect against operating system and other vulnerabilities, says browser flaw would make it possible for attacker to inject rogue software into Vista-based computer; many in computer industry are taking wait-and-see approach to Microsoft's assertions about improved reliability of Vista; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 - Microsoft is facing an early crisis of confidence in the quality of its Windows Vista operating system as computer security researchers and hackers have begun to find potentially serious flaws in the system that was released to corporate customers late last month.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Holding Iranians Seized in Raids in Iraq
articles.snippet: US military is holding at least four Iranians in Iraq, including men Bush administration call senior military officials, who were seized in pair of raids aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces; Bush administration...
articles.abstract: US military is holding at least four Iranians in Iraq, including men Bush administration call senior military officials, who were seized in pair of raids aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces; Bush administration made no public announcement of politically delicate seizure of Iranians, but White House confirms that Iranians are in custody; raids, in Baghdad, have upset Iraqi government officials, who are trying to engage Iran on matters of security; at least two of Iranians are in Iraq on invitation extended by Pres Jalal Talabani during visit to Tehran; one of raids took place in compound of Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, one of Iraq's most powerful Shiite leaders, who recently met with Pres Bush in Washington; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 24 - The American military is holding at least four Iranians in Iraq, including men the Bush administration called senior military officials, who were seized in a pair of raids late last week aimed at people suspected of conducting attacks on Iraqi security forces, according to senior Iraqi and American officials in Baghdad and Washington.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Lots of Cheer From R.I.M., but No News on Options
articles.snippet: Research In Motion chairman and co-chief executive James L Balsillie said quarterly profit was up 47 percent from same period year ago and sales increased 49 percent during investor conference call last week; Balsillie had no comment on review of ...
articles.abstract: Research In Motion chairman and co-chief executive James L Balsillie said quarterly profit was up 47 percent from same period year ago and sales increased 49 percent during investor conference call last week; Balsillie had no comment on review of RIM's stock options grants being undertaken by independent board directors; eight-page letter company submitted at beginning of last week for Ontario Securities Commission hearing only added to uncertainty; it indicated that review was 'proceeding more slowly than anticipated' and that various complications 'substantially increase' $25 million to $45 million in restatements company initially anticipated; lack of information is baffling to investors (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Dec. 24 - James L. Balsillie, the chairman and co-chief executive of Research In Motion, offered plenty of cheery news during an investor conference call last week: quarterly profit up 47 percent from the same period a year ago and a sales increase of 49 percent, largely based on the company's successful move into the consumer market.

articles.headline: Flaws Are Detected in Microsoft’s Vista
articles.snippet: Researchers and hackers have found potentially serious flaws in Microsoft’s new Windows Vista operating system.
articles.abstract: Researchers and hackers have found potentially serious flaws in Microsoft’s new Windows Vista operating system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 — Microsoft is facing an early crisis of confidence in the quality of its Windows Vista operating system as computer security researchers and hackers have begun to find potentially serious flaws in the system that was released to corporate customers late last month.

articles.headline: Sizzling a Year Ago, but Now Pfffft ...
articles.snippet: The telenovela, the steamy low-budget soap opera genre popular in Spanish-speaking countries, has failed to gain traction in the U.S.
articles.abstract: The telenovela, the steamy low-budget soap opera genre popular in Spanish-speaking countries, has failed to gain traction in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: The telenovela, the steamy low-budget soap opera genre that has become the staple of television programming in Spanish-speaking countries, lives on its sudden bursts of uncontrollable — and loudly acted — passion.
